sp.p: There are not any that are fair will hear you.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: And those that are foul I will not pray to.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Follow love: for that makes all things fair and pleasing.

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: I love silence: for in silence my life lives easily, my thoughts freely, and my mind harmoniously.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Sometimes the thoughts disturb the mind, and so the life, more than noise disturbs the thoughts.

sp.speaker: Vain-glor.
sp.p: I love honour: for in honour lives respect.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: I love beauty: for in beauty lives admiration.

sp.speaker: Heroic.
sp.p: I love fame: for in fame lives the memory of the best of my actions.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: I love power: for in power lives adorations.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: I love wit: for that delights myself, and recreates my friends.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: I love eloquence: for that delights my ear.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: But eloquence will deceive your judgement, delude your understanding, and flatter your passions with insinuating persuasions, and will draw you into an erroneous belief, and by that unto unjust actions.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: I love mademoiselle portrait.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: I love monsieur sensuality.

sp.speaker: Heroic.
sp.p: I love mademoiselle ambition.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: I love monsieur heroic.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: I love mademoiselle Bon' esprit.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: I love monsieur satyrical.

sp.speaker: Vain-glor.
sp.p: I love mademoiselle Superbe.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: I love monsieur vainglorious.

sp.speaker: Tranquill.
sp.p: I love mademoiselle Pleasure.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: I love monsieur tranquillitous peace.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: I love mademoiselle faction.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: I love monsieur censure.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: I love ma filia excess.

sp.speaker: Excess.
sp.p: I love monsieur busy.

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: I love ma filia wanton.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: I love monsieur liberty.

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: I love a single life: for in marriage lives too much trouble to live in ease.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: I love to continue a widow: for temperance is banished from most places and persons.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: I love monsieur Frisk; but monsieur Frisk loves not me.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Faith I'll persuade him to love, if not thy person, yet thy wealth; for thou art rich, and he hath hardly enough means to bear up his gentility: besides, one maid and one widow is enough, more would be too much.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: And one bachelor.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Monsieur inquisitive.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Faith 'tis fit and proper he should live a bachelor: for an inquisitive husband would not be good, neither for his own sake, nor his wives.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: But gentlemen and ladies, although you all say you love such a lady, and such a lady loves such a gentleman, yet you do not say you will marry each other.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: You may be sure, if we do publicly profess love, we intend to marry: for though we may love and not marry, or marry and not love, yet not profess it in an open assembly; for love without marriage lives incognito.

sp.speaker: Tranquill.
sp.p: But marriage without love is visible enough: for it lies to the view of all their neighbours knowledge.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Well, noble gentlemen, and virtuous ladies, if you resolve all to marry, I would advise you to marry all in one day.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: O madam temperance, you are sick.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: By reason healthful temperance never gives such surfeiting counsel: for there are as many of us as might be marrying a year, and keeping their festivals, and you would have all married in one day.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Madam temperance means, she would have a whole year as one wedding-day

sp.speaker: Heroic.
sp.p: And one wedding-day to the bride and bridegroom, is as one whole year.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Not to every bride and bridegroom: for on my conscience monsieur Frisk, if he should marry mother matron, will think his wedding-day but a minute long.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: But mother matron will think the day an age.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: You speak so loud, she'll hear you.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: O no, for the most part she is deaf: for she many times stops wool into her ears to keep out the cold.

sp.speaker: 1 gentlem.
sp.p: I hear that wit's cabal is removing out of Cupid's court into Hymen's prison, and there to be bound in bonds of matrimony.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Faith I pity the cabal, and condemn their wit, by reason it did not keep them out of slavery.

sp.speaker: 1 gentleman
sp.p: Wit is both a pander and a traitor: for wit is a pimp in Cupid's court, and betrays his court to Hymen's prison.

sp.speaker: 2 gentleman
sp.p: There are no prisoners look so dejectedly as Hymen's prisoners.

sp.speaker: 1 gentleman
sp.p: There is great reason for it: for they are almost starved for want of variety, and they have less liberty than other prisoners have.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: You hear of the great marriages that are concluded on, and they are to be dispatched out of hand.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Hear of them (Say you) I must stop my ears, and shut my eyes, if I did not both hear and see their preparations: for all the tradesmen are so busily employed, as if they were never to sell or work more after these marriages.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: What tradesmen are those?

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Why tailors, shoemakers, hosiers, seamstresses, feathermen, periwig-makers, perfumers, clothiers, linnengers, silk men, mercers, milliners, haberdashers, curlers, spurriers, saddlers, coach-makers, upholstorers, besides confectioners, cooks, bakers, brewers, butchers, poulterers, and twenty more I cannot think of.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: They will kill and destroy so many creatures for their feasts, that they will make a massacre.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: A famine I think:

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: But there will be great dancings at the court they say: for three will be masks, plays, balls, and such braveries as never was.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: These public weddings, and such public revellings, put the gentry to more charges, than many times they are able to spare; which if it were not for revelling, there would be no need of such vain and idle expenses.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: I mean to be at some charges, as to make me a new suit or two of clothes.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Faith I will spare my purse, and stay at home.

div.head: Scene 25.
div.stage: Enter the several couples, heroic and ambition, tranquillitous peace and pleasure, satyrical and Bon' esprit, vainglorious and Superbe, censure and faction, sensuality and portrait, busy and excess, liberty and wanton, Frisk and mother matron.

sp.speaker: Vainglor.
sp.p: Where will you keep your wedding-feast?

sp.speaker: Heroic.
sp.p: We will keep ours at the court.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: So will we.

sp.speaker: Vain-glor.
sp.p: And so will we.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: And so will we.

sp.speaker: Tranquill.
sp.p: If you please, mistress, we will keep ours in the country.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: I approve of it.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: If my mistress agree, we will keep ours at the playhouse, and feast and dance upon the stage.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: I agree and approve of your choice.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: An ordinary, or tavern, is a more commodious place for the society of the wits: for I am sure all the wits will meet there.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: But if an ordinary, or tavern, be more commodious, yet they are not so public places as the theatres of players; so that wits may be merrier and freer in a tavern, but not so divulged as on a stage in a playhouse.

sp.speaker: Heroic.
sp.p: The truth is, an ordinary or tavern is a more proper place for monsieur sensuality and his mistress to keep their wedding-feast, than for monsieur satyrical and his mistress.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: By your favour, the most proper place for us is the court.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: I think that an hospitable gentleman's house in the country, is most proper for monsieur sensuality to keep his wedding-feast in.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: That is a more proper place for liberty and wanton.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Nay, by your favour, another house (Which shall be nameless, for fear of offending) is fitter for them.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: My honey sweet love, where shall we keep our wedding-feast?

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: For your sake, my sugar-sweeting, we will keep it in bedlam, and monsieur busy and his bride shall keep us company.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Thou art a very wag, my love.

sp.speaker: Tranquil.
sp.p: W' are all agreed.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Pray Jove we speed.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
